title: 113_hr2067
content: The Act titled "Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau Personnel Flexibilities Act" is added to the United States Code, specifically under Chapter 96 for the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau. The Act establishes definitions and applicability for the compensation and performance management system, excluding senior executives and Senior Executive Service positions. The Secretary is tasked with establishing the system. The Secretary is required to establish a system for compensating and managing the performance of employees in critical scientific, technical, or professional positions within the Bureau, with the authority to do so regardless of any limitations in existing laws or regulations. The Secretary must establish a compensation and performance management system for critical positions within the Bureau, consulting with the Director of the Office of Personnel Management. The system cannot exceed 50% of total Bureau positions and must comply with specific provisions of law and regulations. The Secretary must establish a compensation and performance management system for critical positions within the Bureau, consulting with the Director of the Office of Personnel Management. The system must comply with specific provisions of law and regulations, including limitations on compensation and levels of performance. The Secretary must establish a compensation and performance management system for critical positions within the Bureau, consulting with the Director of the Office of Personnel Management. The system must comply with specific provisions of law and regulations, including limitations on compensation and levels of performance. The Secretary, at the request of the Director of the Office of Personnel Management, shall provide information on the operation of any established system. Compliance with preexisting systems is allowed as long as they meet the requirements of the amended chapter 96 of title 5, United States Code. The Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau is referenced in section 9601. The Secretary is required to establish a compensation and performance management system for critical positions within the Bureau, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Personnel Management. Compliance with specific provisions of law and regulations, including limitations on compensation and levels of performance, is necessary. The Secretary must provide information on the operation of any established system upon request from the Director of the Office of Personnel Management. Compliance with preexisting systems is allowed as long as they meet the requirements of the amended chapter 96 of title 5, United States Code. The Government Accountability Office must submit a report to Congress within 1 year of establishing a compensation and performance management system under section 9602 of title 5, United States Code. The report should cover the operation of the system and ongoing demonstration projects testing different pay and classification systems. The Government Accountability Office is required to submit a report to Congress within 1 year of implementing a compensation and performance management system under title 5. The report will assess the effectiveness of the system compared to the General Schedule and provide recommendations for legislative or administrative actions. The appropriate committees of Congress for this report are the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs of the Senate.
